content.description:
Headpoint lead ascent of this old Dave Lane top rope. Great moves up a blunt arete on perfect Murrin granite.

Between "Thriller Off the Void" and "Hotwire"
Used several 5-6 tiny brass nuts in the very incipient seam #0 and 1 RP's and a couple of the smallest metolius aid nuts. Placements are very specific and were rehearsed on rappel, an onsight attempt would probably be better off just ditching the rope altogether. A ground fall would be ugly with many tilted boulders, I used several crash pads just in case.

I didn't really find there to be any crux in this 5.4 walk up. Nice fun place to come if you are just starting out to lead on Traditional Gear.

This route is found by standing at the base of the wall around the corner from the sugurloaf north face, looking up at the hydro tower, Flat Battery is the second crack line from climbers left on that wall. You can walk off or be lowered back down.
Traditional Gear to a bolted anchor above

Starts in the "hole" as for Hot Wire but immediately busts right by way of a tough boulder problem to a thin crack. The climbing above is fun and technical, with excellent movement on great rock. Eventually meanders right to join up with Stairway.

On the north side of the sugarloaf, climber's right if hiking up from the parking lot. Look for the chalked-up basalt hueco. This route climbs up through the large, triangular alcove.
Small nuts and cams. A tiny nut and green C3 protect the boulder problem. Nothing larger than a  #0.5 camalot is needed. Gear is very good, but is often strenuous to place.

Follow a flake and crack up and leftward, through a  blocky scoop and passing abulging overhang. Small cams and nuts can be placed, but gear requires some finesse and thought. Eventually, face climbing on positive edges leads to lower-angle terrain at the top.
content.location: This route is on the Sugarloaf wall, around to the far right side. From the large group of easier climbs, head right, and just past the thin crack/seam "Thriller off the Void".
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. Build a gear anchor at the top, and refrain from using the hydro tower.

content.description:
Grapple through a small roof. Climb direct to the top.

SR to 4". Fixed top anchors.

At the far right-hand edge of the South Wall is a steep corner with a flake on the left, followed by a wide crack. Go up this to a great hand crack above. Without big gear, the wide section is very runout. However, the climbing is easy, past mantles on the right. A groundfall is possible here without gear to 6 inches (or more). Large gear would eliminate the "R" from this route. It is good either way. The crux is right off the ground (unless you decide to throw yourself INTO the wide crack instead of opting for the mantles). Pro to 3.5 inches, or to 6 inches (or more). Requires a GEAR ANCHOR on top. Walk off straight back along the right-hand edge of the cliff.

A groove with a low, wide crack and a bulge near the top.

SR w/ fixed top anchors.

The route is a fairly sustained easy climb.  There are a couple of larger steps that have to be made in the middle.  In all, it's a fun route that can be used either as an introduction to traditional lead climbing or to perfect gear placements.  Essentially, just follow the cracks to the right of the white slab up to the top.

Located beneath the big power-line tower.  Descend climbers right on a rocky trail.
There are two bolts at the top for an anchor.  There are many opportunities for protection.  A set of nuts and Camalot C4s .5-2 would be adequate.

The Mechanic combines face climbing with inconsistent crack moves, for an occasionally heady 5.7 lead.

The Mechanic is found to the left of Flat Battery (the leftmost obvious 5.4 crack) on the central section of the Sugarloaf. There's a lovely walk-off to the north.
Gear is present but rarely a gimme on this climb. A single rack will do. Bolt anchors at the top.

Power Smart is steady, technical face climbing, good at the grade, and bold enough to keep you sweating. Keep your wits about you, and it's a great climb.

Power Smart ascends the face between Flat Battery and Magnet (the left-most and second-to-left 5.4 crack systems) on the central Sugarloaf wall. Look for a vertical white streak at the top to confirm you're in the right spot.
Single rack, including some small gear. Protection is thin and far-between on this climb, unless one uses the adjoining major crack systems. Climbers can use the bolt anchors right or left of the top-out if they're not already in use.
Very engaging and enjoyable climbing on edges and crimps. Exceptionally good movement on steep terrain for the grade. A nice first route for those making the transition from the gym to the outdoors.
content.location: On the far right end of the north side of the sugarloaf. Meander up the broken slab before stepping left onto the main wall.
content.protection: Gear is sparse, but good. Small cams or nuts with nothing bigger than finger-sized. Most choose to top-rope off the easily accessible hydro tower.

climbs.name: Thriller Off the Void
climbs.fa: FA (Top rope) Royal Robbins, Jim Sinclair 1971, FA Dave Lane 1978

content.description:
The Bourdon guide unaccountably designates this pleasant pitch a super classic.  Far easier in the grade than the nearby Block and Tackle. 
  
 On the north side of Sugarloaf, climb left facing corner with a wide crack.  Pull up onto the face and climb an 80+ degree face with some fingerlocks past three bolts; the crux moves between bolts two and three are pretty easy if you identify the footholds before launching into the sequence.  Belay off the power tower.

On the north side of Sugarloaf.
Three bolts, maybe and nut or two and a #3 and/or #4 Camalot for the start.

This very popular crag offers two different faces to the world.  A south side with six routes from 5.4 to 5.8, combined with access to the top and bolted anchors, guarantees that you will not be alone here if you can find  a free climb at all.  A great place to learn to climb or lead trad.  The north side has much harder and more interesting climbing.  Again, the access to the top ensures that there are often top-ropes on these although most are good leads.
